Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: A I04iend on their way to the airport calls, thinking they left their passport at home, and asks if you can check and bring it to them right away.
Expectation2: Perform assigned physical tasks and material handling efficiently.
Situation2: The supervisor has asked you to move a stack of unused materials to a different storage area sometime before the end of the day.
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was hauling a load of bricks across the site. It was Sam, my oldest friend, his voice tight with panic. “I think I left my passport at home. I’m almost at the airport—can you check and bring it if it’s there? Please, I’ll miss my flight otherwise.” I glanced at the clock; there was still a mountain of materials to move before the end of my shift, and the supervisor had made it clear it had to be done today. My hands were already raw, my back aching, but Sam had always been there for me, especially when things got rough. I could hear the desperation in his voice, and I knew how much this trip meant to him. But if I left now, I’d be letting down my crew, maybe even risking my job. The weight of both expectations pressed down on me, my mind racing as I tried to figure out what to do, torn between loyalty to my friend and responsibility to my work.
